<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: PowerPC is incorrectly formatted in the Tiers on downloads
username_0: PowerPC should like the x86-64 musl entry above. It is showing up in the first two columns instead of the last two. It is unclear why this is happening. The page source looks fine to me.

![Screen Shot 2020-07-10 at 5 43 29 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/744411/87205209-ea6ba580-c2d4-11ea-87b6-a2c3394d2343.png)
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_1 Might you know why this is happening?
<issue_comment>username_1: I‚Äôll have a look today, thanks for the ping, maybe @zdroid has an idea too<issue_closed>

[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'centralizedtransformer', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2021-07-26 16:21:36+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': "**Is your wallet globally accessible?**
Yes, Atomic is a decentralized wallet that can be accessed from anywhere with no KYC and verification for basic features.

**Is your wallet custodial, non-custodial, or a hardware wallet?**
Atomic is a non-custodial wallet. It‚Äôs simply an interface with private and public keys and to sign transactions. Users‚Äô funds are always accessible on blockchains.

**Please describe the measures taken to ensure the wallet's security and provide documentation wherever possible**
Atomic Wallet Privacy Policy is stated here. Atomic is also continuously tested by our QA team and senior software engineers to ensure it complies with global security standards. Before the launch of our product, it has to pass a penetration test, security test, and vulnerability test. We've had zero security compromises in our app's history. Moreover, we have a bug bounty campaign and warmly welcome any suggestions and reports from our users.


**Does the wallet have fiat on-ramps?**
Yes, our users can buy top crypto assets with VISA/MC of 18 global fiat currencies. The service is provided by Simplex, 5% fees (min. $10 USD) are included in the price.


**Does the wallet allow users to explore dapps?**
Atomic is integrated with WalletConnect.


**Does the wallet have integrated defi/financial tools?**
No.


**Can a user withdraw to their card?**
Not yet.


**Does the wallet offer limits protection?**
The limit for transfers exists only in the sense of the KYC process. Until a customer buys crypto up to $200, they don‚Äôt need to pass the verification.


**Does the wallet allow high-volume purchases?**
Yes, a user can buy $2000+ worth of crypto in one go, passing KYC powered by Simplex.


**Does the wallet have an integrated token swap?**
Yes, Atomic has an exchange service directly in the wallet. Service is provided by ChangeNOW. There are more than 60 crypto pairs available for the swaps.


**Is the wallet a multi-signature wallet?**
No


**Wallet title**
Atomic Wallet

**Wallet description**
Atomic is a decentralized cryptocurrency wallet that supports more than 500 coins and tokens, providing simplicity, safety, and convenience for its users.


**Wallet logo**
https://atomicwallet.io/images/press-kit/atomic_wallet_logo_white_vert_2.png


**Background colour for brand logo**
Dark-Blue Background: 212D4D, Light-Blue Color: Gradient, top ‚Äì 3EBBF, bottom ‚Äì 1F8EFA


**URL**
https://atomicwallet.io/", 'title': "Add Atomic Wallet to the wallet's section", 'type': 'issue'}

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Add Atomic Wallet to the wallet's section
username_0: **Is your wallet globally accessible?**
Yes, Atomic is a decentralized wallet that can be accessed from anywhere with no KYC and verification for basic features.

**Is your wallet custodial, non-custodial, or a hardware wallet?**
Atomic is a non-custodial wallet. It‚Äôs simply an interface with private and public keys and to sign transactions. Users‚Äô funds are always accessible on blockchains.

**Please describe the measures taken to ensure the wallet's security and provide documentation wherever possible**
Atomic Wallet Privacy Policy is stated here. Atomic is also continuously tested by our QA team and senior software engineers to ensure it complies with global security standards. Before the launch of our product, it has to pass a penetration test, security test, and vulnerability test. We've had zero security compromises in our app's history. Moreover, we have a bug bounty campaign and warmly welcome any suggestions and reports from our users.


**Does the wallet have fiat on-ramps?**
Yes, our users can buy top crypto assets with VISA/MC of 18 global fiat currencies. The service is provided by Simplex, 5% fees (min. $10 USD) are included in the price.


**Does the wallet allow users to explore dapps?**
Atomic is integrated with WalletConnect.


**Does the wallet have integrated defi/financial tools?**
No.


**Can a user withdraw to their card?**
Not yet.


**Does the wallet offer limits protection?**
The limit for transfers exists only in the sense of the KYC process. Until a customer buys crypto up to $200, they don‚Äôt need to pass the verification.


**Does the wallet allow high-volume purchases?**
Yes, a user can buy $2000+ worth of crypto in one go, passing KYC powered by Simplex.


**Does the wallet have an integrated token swap?**
Yes, Atomic has an exchange service directly in the wallet. Service is provided by ChangeNOW. There are more than 60 crypto pairs available for the swaps.


**Is the wallet a multi-signature wallet?**
No


**Wallet title**
Atomic Wallet

**Wallet description**
Atomic is a decentralized cryptocurrency wallet that supports more than 500 coins and tokens, providing simplicity, safety, and convenience for its users.


**Wallet logo**
https://atomicwallet.io/images/press-kit/atomic_wallet_logo_white_vert_2.png


**Background colour for brand logo**
Dark-Blue Background: 212D4D, Light-Blue Color: Gradient, top ‚Äì 3EBBF, bottom ‚Äì 1F8EFA


**URL**
https://atomicwallet.io/
<issue_comment>username_1: Hey @username_0 ! A few details we need to iron out. [Per our content policy](https://ethereum.org/en/contributing/adding-products/), wallets need to have been audited and maintained by an active team:

- Where can we confirm the wallet's last audit?

- Is the Atomic Wallet team active? (I assume so, but just checking!)

Thanks!
<issue_comment>username_1: @username_0 hey! Any update on this üò¨?
<issue_comment>username_1: @username_0 closing this out for now. Feel free to reopen with the necessary information ‚ò∫Ô∏è<issue_closed>
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_1 Hi Joshua! It's Andrew from the Atomic Wallet team. First of all sorry for not replying to your comments.


We are ready to send you the audit in dm. We have it in pdf format. Please provide us with contacts where we can send it. 

Regarding the team, we constantly updating the app and maintaining our own validators and nodes, so the team is pretty active. You may check out the website and social media as proof: https://twitter.com/atomicwallet

[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'fahali', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2021-08-15 17:25:43+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'The [GenServer chapter](https://elixir-lang.org/getting-started/mix-otp/genserver.html) in the Getting Started guide for Elixir closes by introducing process monitoring. Before moving on to the next chapter, I ran `mix test`. The tests for `KV.Registry` do not pass. Here is the output of `mix test`:
```powershell
13:05:52.321 [error] GenServer #PID<0.167.0> terminating
** (FunctionClauseError) no function clause matching in KV.Registry.handle_cast/2
    (kv 0.1.0) lib/kv/registry.ex:45: KV.Registry.handle_cast({:create, "shopping"}, %{})
    (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:637: :gen_server.try_dispatch/4
    (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:711: :gen_server.handle_msg/6
    (stdlib 3.12) proc_lib.erl:249: :proc_lib.init_p_do_apply/3
Last message: {:"$gen_cast", {:create, "shopping"}}
State: %{}

13:05:52.336 [error] GenServer #PID<0.171.0> terminating
** (MatchError) no match of right hand side value: %{"shopping" => #PID<0.172.0>}
    (kv 0.1.0) lib/kv/registry.ex:40: KV.Registry.handle_call/3
    (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:661: :gen_server.try_handle_call/4
    (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:690: :gen_server.handle_msg/6
    (stdlib 3.12) proc_lib.erl:249: :proc_lib.init_p_do_apply/3
Last message (from #PID<0.169.0>): {:lookup, "shopping"}
State: %{"shopping" => #PID<0.172.0>}
Client #PID<0.169.0> is alive

    (stdlib 3.12) gen.erl:167: :gen.do_call/4
    (elixir 1.12.1) lib/gen_server.ex:1021: GenServer.call/3
    test/kv/registry_test.exs:23: KV.RegistryTest."test removes buckets on exit"/1
    (ex_unit 1.12.1) lib/ex_unit/runner.ex:502: ExUnit.Runner.exec_test/1
    (stdlib 3.12) timer.erl:166: :timer.tc/1
    (ex_unit 1.12.1) lib/ex_unit/runner.ex:453: anonymous fn/4 in ExUnit.Runner.spawn_test_monitor/4


  1) test spawns buckets (KV.RegistryTest)
     test/kv/registry_test.exs:9
     ** (exit) exited in: GenServer.call(#PID<0.167.0>, {:lookup, "shopping"}, 5000)
        ** (EXIT) an exception was raised:
          ** (FunctionClauseError) no function clause matching in KV.Registry.handle_cast/2
     
          The following arguments were given to KV.Registry.handle_cast/2:

              # 1
              {:create, "shopping"}

              # 2
              %{}

          Attempted function clauses (showing 1 out of 1):

              def handle_cast({:create, name}, -{names, refs}-)

          stacktrace:
            (kv 0.1.0) lib/kv/registry.ex:45: KV.Registry.handle_cast/2
            (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:637: :gen_server.try_dispatch/4
            (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:711: :gen_server.handle_msg/6

       (elixir 1.12.1) lib/gen_server.ex:1024: GenServer.call/3
       test/kv/registry_test.exs:13: (test)



  2) test removes buckets on exit (KV.RegistryTest)
     test/kv/registry_test.exs:19
     ** (exit) exited in: GenServer.call(#PID<0.171.0>, {:lookup, "shopping"}, 5000)
         ** (EXIT) an exception was raised:
             ** (MatchError) no match of right hand side value: %{"shopping" => #PID<0.172.0>}
                 (kv 0.1.0) lib/kv/registry.ex:40: KV.Registry.handle_call/3
                 (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:661: :gen_server.try_handle_call/4
                 (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:690: :gen_server.handle_msg/6
                 (stdlib 3.12) proc_lib.erl:249: :proc_lib.init_p_do_apply/3
     code: assert KV.Registry.lookup(registry, "shopping") == :error
     stacktrace:
       (elixir 1.12.1) lib/gen_server.ex:1024: GenServer.call/3
       test/kv/registry_test.exs:23: (test)
```
I am learning Elixir for the first time, so I am not sure how to proceed with fixing the tests to make them pass. However, my assumption is that we are testing the client API of our `KV.Registry` module, so modifying the server callbacks should not have affected the tests. Here is the code for the `KV.Registry` module, and the corresponding tests:
### KV/lib/kv/registry.ex
```elixir
defmodule KV.Registry do
  use GenServer

  ## Client API

  @doc """
[Truncated]
  end

  test "spawns buckets", %{registry: registry} do
    assert KV.Registry.lookup(registry, "shopping") == :error

    KV.Registry.create(registry, "shopping")
    assert {:ok, bucket} = KV.Registry.lookup(registry, "shopping")

    KV.Bucket.put(bucket, "milk", 1)
    assert KV.Bucket.get(bucket, "milk") == 1
  end

  test "removes buckets on exit", %{registry: registry} do
    KV.Registry.create(registry, "shopping")
    {:ok, bucket} = KV.Registry.lookup(registry, "shopping")
    Agent.stop(bucket)
    assert KV.Registry.lookup(registry, "shopping") == :error
  end
end
```', 'title': 'Getting Started - GenServer: Modifying server callbacks to monitor processes breaks unit tests', 'type': 'issue'}

Your handle_call is wrong. You are returning only the ‚Äúnames‚Äù as the state, instead of the {names, refs} tuple, causing further invocations to fail. :)', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}

I should definitely be more careful in reading over the example code in the tutorial. Thank you!', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}]
column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Getting Started - GenServer: Modifying server callbacks to monitor processes breaks unit tests
username_0: The [GenServer chapter](https://elixir-lang.org/getting-started/mix-otp/genserver.html) in the Getting Started guide for Elixir closes by introducing process monitoring. Before moving on to the next chapter, I ran `mix test`. The tests for `KV.Registry` do not pass. Here is the output of `mix test`:
```powershell
13:05:52.321 [error] GenServer #PID<0.167.0> terminating
** (FunctionClauseError) no function clause matching in KV.Registry.handle_cast/2
    (kv 0.1.0) lib/kv/registry.ex:45: KV.Registry.handle_cast({:create, "shopping"}, %{})
    (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:637: :gen_server.try_dispatch/4
    (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:711: :gen_server.handle_msg/6
    (stdlib 3.12) proc_lib.erl:249: :proc_lib.init_p_do_apply/3
Last message: {:"$gen_cast", {:create, "shopping"}}
State: %{}

13:05:52.336 [error] GenServer #PID<0.171.0> terminating
** (MatchError) no match of right hand side value: %{"shopping" => #PID<0.172.0>}
    (kv 0.1.0) lib/kv/registry.ex:40: KV.Registry.handle_call/3
    (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:661: :gen_server.try_handle_call/4
    (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:690: :gen_server.handle_msg/6
    (stdlib 3.12) proc_lib.erl:249: :proc_lib.init_p_do_apply/3
Last message (from #PID<0.169.0>): {:lookup, "shopping"}
State: %{"shopping" => #PID<0.172.0>}
Client #PID<0.169.0> is alive

    (stdlib 3.12) gen.erl:167: :gen.do_call/4
    (elixir 1.12.1) lib/gen_server.ex:1021: GenServer.call/3
    test/kv/registry_test.exs:23: KV.RegistryTest."test removes buckets on exit"/1
    (ex_unit 1.12.1) lib/ex_unit/runner.ex:502: ExUnit.Runner.exec_test/1
    (stdlib 3.12) timer.erl:166: :timer.tc/1
    (ex_unit 1.12.1) lib/ex_unit/runner.ex:453: anonymous fn/4 in ExUnit.Runner.spawn_test_monitor/4


  1) test spawns buckets (KV.RegistryTest)
     test/kv/registry_test.exs:9
     ** (exit) exited in: GenServer.call(#PID<0.167.0>, {:lookup, "shopping"}, 5000)
        ** (EXIT) an exception was raised:
          ** (FunctionClauseError) no function clause matching in KV.Registry.handle_cast/2
     
          The following arguments were given to KV.Registry.handle_cast/2:

              # 1
              {:create, "shopping"}

              # 2
              %{}

          Attempted function clauses (showing 1 out of 1):

              def handle_cast({:create, name}, -{names, refs}-)

          stacktrace:
            (kv 0.1.0) lib/kv/registry.ex:45: KV.Registry.handle_cast/2
            (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:637: :gen_server.try_dispatch/4
            (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:711: :gen_server.handle_msg/6

       (elixir 1.12.1) lib/gen_server.ex:1024: GenServer.call/3
       test/kv/registry_test.exs:13: (test)



  2) test removes buckets on exit (KV.RegistryTest)
     test/kv/registry_test.exs:19
     ** (exit) exited in: GenServer.call(#PID<0.171.0>, {:lookup, "shopping"}, 5000)
         ** (EXIT) an exception was raised:
             ** (MatchError) no match of right hand side value: %{"shopping" => #PID<0.172.0>}
                 (kv 0.1.0) lib/kv/registry.ex:40: KV.Registry.handle_call/3
                 (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:661: :gen_server.try_handle_call/4
                 (stdlib 3.12) gen_server.erl:690: :gen_server.handle_msg/6
                 (stdlib 3.12) proc_lib.erl:249: :proc_lib.init_p_do_apply/3
     code: assert KV.Registry.lookup(registry, "shopping") == :error
     stacktrace:
       (elixir 1.12.1) lib/gen_server.ex:1024: GenServer.call/3
       test/kv/registry_test.exs:23: (test)
```
I am learning Elixir for the first time, so I am not sure how to proceed with fixing the tests to make them pass. However, my assumption is that we are testing the client API of our `KV.Registry` module, so modifying the server callbacks should not have affected the tests. Here is the code for the `KV.Registry` module, and the corresponding tests:
### KV/lib/kv/registry.ex
```elixir
defmodule KV.Registry do
  use GenServer

  ## Client API

  @doc """
[Truncated]
  end

  test "spawns buckets", %{registry: registry} do
    assert KV.Registry.lookup(registry, "shopping") == :error

    KV.Registry.create(registry, "shopping")
    assert {:ok, bucket} = KV.Registry.lookup(registry, "shopping")

    KV.Bucket.put(bucket, "milk", 1)
    assert KV.Bucket.get(bucket, "milk") == 1
  end

  test "removes buckets on exit", %{registry: registry} do
    KV.Registry.create(registry, "shopping")
    {:ok, bucket} = KV.Registry.lookup(registry, "shopping")
    Agent.stop(bucket)
    assert KV.Registry.lookup(registry, "shopping") == :error
  end
end
```
<issue_comment>username_1: Welcome! üëã 

Your handle_call is wrong. You are returning only the ‚Äúnames‚Äù as the state, instead of the {names, refs} tuple, causing further invocations to fail. :)<issue_closed>
<issue_comment>username_0: Wow, that was so simple. I should definitely be more careful in reading over the example code in the tutorial. Thank you!

column5:
[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'mitdralla', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2021-11-11 17:59:39+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': "**Is your wallet security tested? Please explain security measures i.e. security audit, internal security team or some other method.**

<!-- Please explain any security measures you have taken to ensure your wallet is secure -->

The app is constantly subject to multiple layers of QA testing before (and after) undergoing internal audits and penetration tests. Major releases undergo 3rd party security auditing.

Numio is a non-custodial mobile application focused on user security and UI/UX. A user's key pair is generated locally on their phone and their private keys never leave their device. Users sign their own transactions manually and only the encrypted data is transmitted.


**When did your wallet go live to users?**

<!-- Please provide an exact or approximate date when your wallet was usable by the public -->

Android went live on Google Play on the 31st December 2020 and iOS went live in the App Store on the 6th July 2021.


**Does your wallet have an active development team?**

<!-- Are developers actively working on the wallet? -->

Yes. The wallet is actively developed and new releases go out on average every 10 days.


**Is your wallet open-source?**

<!-- If yes, please provide a direct link to the repository, if you can -->

No. Numio is not open source, however elements of the application are.

Open source elements include our CDN & SDK, zkSync API, NPM relayer, and various meta API‚Äôs.

Our full open-source GitHub repo can be found here - https://github.com/TeamNumio/TeamNumio

**Is your wallet globally accessible?**

<!-- Please list any KYC requirements or geographic limitations of your wallet, if any exist. -->

Numio is globally accessible via the Google Play and Apple App Stores. The app requires no KYC to use.



**Is your wallet custodial, non-custodial, or a hardware wallet?**

<!-- Do users have access to their public and/or private keys? If your company/project were to disappear, would users still be able to access their funds? -->

Numio is non-custodial - only the user has access to their Private Keys, which are easily accessible via the settings menu.

**Please describe the measures taken to ensure the wallet's security and provide documentation wherever possible**

<!-- Please provide a link to a report or repo. If you haven't been audited but think your wallet should be listed anyway, explain here. -->

As stated in the first response, the app is constantly subject to multiple layers of QA testing before (and after) undergoing internal audits and penetration tests. Major releases undergo 3rd party security auditing. While we do not currently have any of this audit data currently publicly available, we are looking to make something available in the near future.

We work closely with our partners, including zkSync and Storj, to ensure that their technology is integrated in accordance with their best practices. This can be verified with those teams.

Outside of secure blockchain technology, the Numio application uses SHA256/RSA256 for encryption both within the app, and as a byproduct of integrated technology, including FaceTech - https://dev.facetec.com/security-best-practices.

Numio has now been public for over 11 months, and has been downloaded in excess of 10,000 times from Google Play and the App Store. There has not been a single significant security bug reported in that time. It is also worth noting that both the application and company were subject to significant due diligence by VC‚Äôs as part of our $1.25m seed investment round which was completed in July 2021.


**Does the wallet have fiat on-ramps?**

<!-- Does the wallet subsidise transaction fees for all or some wallet activity? -->

Layer 1 ERC-20 tokens can be purchased with credit & debit cards. Layer 2 fiat on-ramps are in the process of being added.

Numio utilizes zkRollups from zkSync to reduce transaction fees for the user. Additional Layer 2 solutions are currently being integrated.

**Does the wallet allow users to explore dapps?**

<!-- Is the wallet integrated with WalletConnect? Does it have a dapp browser? Or can users connect to a dapp using the wallet?  -->

As of version 2.3, Numio is integrated with Wallet Connect. Users can simply scan a QR code and connect with their favorite dapp right from the Numio app.

**Does the wallet have integrated defi/financial tools?**

<!-- Can users borrow/earn/lend assets directly from a screen in the wallet?  -->

Borrowing, Lending and earning are not currently integrated - however these features are being added in a future update. 

[Truncated]
Numio is a non-custodial, Layer 2 Ethereum wallet, powered by zkRollups for fast and cheap ERC-20 transactions and token swaps. Numio is available on Android and iOS.


**Wallet logo**

<!-- Please provide a hi-res SVG or transparent PNG -->

All brand assets can be found at - https://www.numio.one/brand-kit/

**Background colour for brand logo**

<!-- Please provide a hex code for the brand color. This will be added to the background of the wallet card. -->

#3AD15D

**URL**

<!-- Please provide a URL (e.g. to the website of the wallet). -->

https://numio.one", 'title': 'Wallet Listing: Numio', 'type': 'issue'}

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Wallet Listing: Numio
username_0: **Is your wallet security tested? Please explain security measures i.e. security audit, internal security team or some other method.**

<!-- Please explain any security measures you have taken to ensure your wallet is secure -->

The app is constantly subject to multiple layers of QA testing before (and after) undergoing internal audits and penetration tests. Major releases undergo 3rd party security auditing.

Numio is a non-custodial mobile application focused on user security and UI/UX. A user's key pair is generated locally on their phone and their private keys never leave their device. Users sign their own transactions manually and only the encrypted data is transmitted.


**When did your wallet go live to users?**

<!-- Please provide an exact or approximate date when your wallet was usable by the public -->

Android went live on Google Play on the 31st December 2020 and iOS went live in the App Store on the 6th July 2021.


**Does your wallet have an active development team?**

<!-- Are developers actively working on the wallet? -->

Yes. The wallet is actively developed and new releases go out on average every 10 days.


**Is your wallet open-source?**

<!-- If yes, please provide a direct link to the repository, if you can -->

No. Numio is not open source, however elements of the application are.

Open source elements include our CDN & SDK, zkSync API, NPM relayer, and various meta API‚Äôs.

Our full open-source GitHub repo can be found here - https://github.com/TeamNumio/TeamNumio

**Is your wallet globally accessible?**

<!-- Please list any KYC requirements or geographic limitations of your wallet, if any exist. -->

Numio is globally accessible via the Google Play and Apple App Stores. The app requires no KYC to use.



**Is your wallet custodial, non-custodial, or a hardware wallet?**

<!-- Do users have access to their public and/or private keys? If your company/project were to disappear, would users still be able to access their funds? -->

Numio is non-custodial - only the user has access to their Private Keys, which are easily accessible via the settings menu.

**Please describe the measures taken to ensure the wallet's security and provide documentation wherever possible**

<!-- Please provide a link to a report or repo. If you haven't been audited but think your wallet should be listed anyway, explain here. -->

As stated in the first response, the app is constantly subject to multiple layers of QA testing before (and after) undergoing internal audits and penetration tests. Major releases undergo 3rd party security auditing. While we do not currently have any of this audit data currently publicly available, we are looking to make something available in the near future.

We work closely with our partners, including zkSync and Storj, to ensure that their technology is integrated in accordance with their best practices. This can be verified with those teams.

Outside of secure blockchain technology, the Numio application uses SHA256/RSA256 for encryption both within the app, and as a byproduct of integrated technology, including FaceTech - https://dev.facetec.com/security-best-practices.

Numio has now been public for over 11 months, and has been downloaded in excess of 10,000 times from Google Play and the App Store. There has not been a single significant security bug reported in that time. It is also worth noting that both the application and company were subject to significant due diligence by VC‚Äôs as part of our $1.25m seed investment round which was completed in July 2021.


**Does the wallet have fiat on-ramps?**

<!-- Does the wallet subsidise transaction fees for all or some wallet activity? -->

Layer 1 ERC-20 tokens can be purchased with credit & debit cards. Layer 2 fiat on-ramps are in the process of being added.

Numio utilizes zkRollups from zkSync to reduce transaction fees for the user. Additional Layer 2 solutions are currently being integrated.

**Does the wallet allow users to explore dapps?**

<!-- Is the wallet integrated with WalletConnect? Does it have a dapp browser? Or can users connect to a dapp using the wallet?  -->

As of version 2.3, Numio is integrated with Wallet Connect. Users can simply scan a QR code and connect with their favorite dapp right from the Numio app.

**Does the wallet have integrated defi/financial tools?**

<!-- Can users borrow/earn/lend assets directly from a screen in the wallet?  -->

Borrowing, Lending and earning are not currently integrated - however these features are being added in a future update. 

[Truncated]
Numio is a non-custodial, Layer 2 Ethereum wallet, powered by zkRollups for fast and cheap ERC-20 transactions and token swaps. Numio is available on Android and iOS.


**Wallet logo**

<!-- Please provide a hi-res SVG or transparent PNG -->

All brand assets can be found at - https://www.numio.one/brand-kit/

**Background colour for brand logo**

<!-- Please provide a hex code for the brand color. This will be added to the background of the wallet card. -->

#3AD15D

**URL**

<!-- Please provide a URL (e.g. to the website of the wallet). -->

https://numio.one
<issue_comment>username_0: Hello :) - I added an addition to one of the questions:

"Device permissions are only requested based on a user's choice of function and if essential to the operation of the application. Any permissions are at the minimum viable amount to ensure that a function works. Numio keeps up to date with all Google Play and App Store privacy requirements and describes, via custom modal and plain English, exactly what each permission is for.

By design, users are unable to capture the screen during the seed phrase screen and (optional) biometrics registrations screens to enhance users security. Seed phrases are not stored on the device."
<issue_comment>username_0: Hello @username_1 üëãüèº  please let me know if you need any more information from us on the Numio listing - Thank you<issue_closed>
<issue_comment>username_2: Hello @username_1, thanks for the Numio listing.

I just wanted to point out that there is a mistake in the listing as the wallet does support Token Swaps but the features card says it doesn't.

Also, if possible could the background colour for the logo be changed from white to #3F3F3F or should we submit a logo with this background?

Thank you for your help.

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Add glamorous-native to Integrations
username_0: Would love to see [glamorous-native](https://github.com/robinpowered/glamorous-native) as an integration, and perhaps a section(?).

I won't be able to get to this in the short term, so anyone who'd like to take a stab, that'd be awesome!
<issue_comment>username_1: It exists in the ["basics"](https://rc.glamorous.rocks/basics#glamorous-native) but maybe it should get its own page?
<issue_comment>username_0: I think having its own page would be ideal since it could use a handful of examples
<issue_comment>username_1: This project is now in an unmaintained status. Please see [the glamorous README](https://github.com/paypal/glamorous) for more information.<issue_closed>
